repository.name: 1590A
repository.description: Random odd guitar pedal design in kicad

commit.message:
Try LDO for positive voltage rail cleaning

As mentioned, I don't think I'll actually build this, because it seems
pointlessly complicated.  But I did the basic design and layout for it
just in case.

I think I'll go back to the single-rail design and keep the MOSFET
switching.

I also think I need to come up with a new project.  I'm kind of running
out of ideas of small projects to do that I can build and test.  I like
the switching circuit, but I'm losing interest in the effects board side
since I still can't actually play guitar.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add AP2202-ADJ LDO symbol to my parts library

I don't think I'll actually end up using this, because the negative
voltage generation just ends up being more pain than it is worth, but I
think I'll do one last test-run of things with a nice linear voltage
regulator to make that positive rail more solid.

I've been here before: I'd like to have a dual rail voltage for so many
reasons, but the end result is just rather noisy.  Not just on the
actual negative rail, but on the incoming positive rail too.  The dual
inductor thing does seem less noisy than most, but it still requires
just more work.

Even the traditional charge pump wasn't great.

It's all fixable, but the fixes tend to end up making things more
complicated than simply rebiasing the signal to the middle of the
positive rail.

This is made much worse by the whole "modular base and effects board"
approach I have taken: it means that the base board then always ends up
being overly complicated, when the effect board may not need a negative
rail at all, or may not need very much power at all.

In fact, it might not need the signal being re-bias back to ground
because in many cases the effects board will rebias the signal anyway.

So this is all self-inflicted pain.  But I'll continue doing this simply
because I'm trying things out, and certainly learning things in the
process.

I do note that my plain base board is very simple and works really quite
well, but does rely on clean power input.  So it wants a good low-noise
guitar pedal power supply.  Which is admittedly not that hard to find,
and kind of expected for most guitar pedals.  I then mess things up with
my own power supply games.

But here we are: add a LDO to allow cleaning up the mess that generating
that negative rail results in.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Update the buffered base board

The JFET switching worked fine, but since this all started as an
exercise in using MOSFETs, let's just go all in on that, and use the
MOSFETs for switching the signal too.

Due to the body diode, you need two MOSFETs in series for the signal
switching, so it's four MOSFETs instead of two JFETs, but despite that
the end result is actually simpler.  And those dual MOSFET things are
common and dirt cheap, unlike the special matched JFET package.

Since I can just continue to use the dual complementary MOSFETs, I can
use PMOS for one signal and NMOS for the other, and share all the gate
circuit.  Plus no need for a diode to protect the gate current messing
with the signal.

Also update the resistor value in the switching circuit and make the
time constant be 100ms.  That seems to make it more reliable in testing,
although I'm not convinced my testing with the original value was all
that great.  The soft-switch circuit does seem to work, though.

Also, since the LED pin on the board connectors has never been used,
let's just re-purpose that as a negative voltage pin for the effect
board.  If some effect board wants to touch the LED status, it might as
well just connect to the LED itself.  Having access to a dual voltage
rail would seem to be a lot more important.

Finally - and probably most importantly for actual sound and current
effects boards - add a low-pass filter on the voltage lines.  Because as
expected, the negative power supply did add a lot of noise to the VIN
line.

The base board itself doesn't actually care, but the effects boards do.

An actual LDO would be better, but I don't have any simple fixed ones in
my parts library (except for the 5V one, which seems a bit sad).
Current effects boards don't use a lot of current and only care about
the voltage being stable, so let's try this simple model.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Buffered base: use negative rail for JFET switching

This _still_ doesn't do any actual buffering, but with the negative
rail, we now no longer need to rebase the signals to some mid-point
voltage, and we can just leave the signals ground-references and use the
negative rail for switching.

That streamlines the signal path, and will make it easier to just insert
an opamp or two in there too.  But I remain more interested in getting
the switching side sorted out properly, so that's the primary goal here.

This tweaks the push-on push-off circuit a bit too, since taht one now
needs to switch between positive and negative voltages rather than VIN
and ground.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add negative power rail to the buffered base design

The negative voltage isn't actually _used_ anywhere yet, but this is
prep-work for making that buffered base board do the long promised
buffering, as I'm currently leaning towards opamps.

The LT3462A is very easy to use, but in a probably completely misguided
attempt at keeping any stray ground return currents on the power supply
side, I added a ground plane keepout.  No isolation, but an attempt to
at least make the easy path for any return currents to stay in that
"power supply area" and hopefully not show up around the analog parts.

Somebody who knows what they are about would probably tell me I'm just
making things worse.  But I'm a sw engineer, so pretty much by
definition I don't know anybody who knows what they are doing.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add LT3462A symbol

I'm going to experiment with a negative power rail one more time, and in
the LT3462A I found a DC/DC converter that looks a lot more pleasant
than the ones I've tried before.

Not only is it a nice TSOT-23-6 footprint, but it has an integrated
schottky diode so it's easy to use.  And it's a fixed frequency dual
inductor inverter design, so it should be reasonably quiet in the audio
frequency.

I'm not planning to bother with LDOs to clean up the power rails,
because the reason for the power rail would be the op-amp for buffering,
and the PSRR of any quality opamp should make it all irrelevant.

I dunno.  Every time I've tried this, it's just been noise hell, so this
is probably a bad idea.  Even when you can't actually _hear_ the noise,
it ends up just messing with the signal on the scope and making it
harder to judge whether the circuit is doing well or not.  But I keep
trying.

What was the definition of insanity again? I forget.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Split the buffered base over multiple schematic pages, do PCB layout

So this thing is still mis-named, in that it doesn't actually buffer the
signal at all, it only does the transistor soft-switching.  But I _will_
add buffering at some point, it's just not the interesting part of this
all, since I've done that part before.

But because I wrote explanations for the push-on / push-off circuit, and
because I split things up into small parts, the schematic was getting
pretty crowded.  So I decided to split up the actually interesting part
of the schematic - the switching side - onto a schematic page of its
own.

And while doing that, I moved the simulation infrastructure to its own
page too.

That leaves the toplevel page pretty empty with mainly just the
connectors and the basic signal and power filtering, but that's where
the buffers will go eventually.

And because it simulates fine, I want to actually see if it works in
reality.  So this also does the PCB layout.  There's tons of room left
for any future buffering circuit, whether I then do it with discrete
JFETs or decide that op-amps are the sane thing here.

I used a random regular tactile switch - which I don't actually have in
my parts library.  I'll just wire up two wires and test it that way (and
I do have some momentary SPDT stomp switches around that I can attach to
the wires).

But longer-term, one of the points of this kind of electronic switching
is that you can do it multiple ways, and aren't limited to a physical
switch - or indeed just a single one.  So maybe I'll do some remote
switching thing, or play around with using a hall effect sensor and a
magnet, or whatever.

There are always new things to learn about...  But let's make sure the
basics of this thing actually works first.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Buffered base: add RF filter after JFET switches

It turns out that getting rid of the switching pop seems to be as simple
as that.

Maybe time to do PCB layout and see if reality matches simulation?

I do think I should do the buffer that this doesn't do despite the name.
That was the intent, but then it worked so well without it..  An op-amp
would be the sane thing to do, but since I've been on a "discrete
components" tear, I suspect I'd just do a JFET voltage follower.

But then I feel like I should make up for the inevitable signal loss.
Or use a common source thing that does a phase reversal? That seems
wrong too.  Perhaps do another dual JFET for a common source both at
input and output?

Decisions, decisions.

Anyway, this doesn't do any of that.  This just gets rid of the
switching pop in simulation.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Wire the soft-switch up to actually switch signal and LED

Surprisingly, this actually seems to work fine.  In simulation only, of
course.

And not surprisingly, according to the same simulation, it has an
impressively horrible pop at switching time.  This very much reminds me
of the broken "Tremolo doubling as a metronome" thing, which was due to
the exact same thing: very harsh and sudden driving of the JFET gate.

It's made worse by the MOSFET switching having the same thing.  Big
voltage spike when turning off, presumably due to capacitive parasitics
or whatever.

Possibly helped by adding a resistor at the gate or something, but
unlike the tremolo, the switching event is rare.  So right now I simply
don't care.  I'm just _simulating_ switching things at a 5Hz rate, so it
shows up like a sore thumb.

I haven't done layout, and I haven't added a real switch yet, so this is
all just simulation.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add the beginnings of a dubious buffered base board

As part of looking at what I should try to use my MOSFETs for, I decided
I should finally look at a soft-switch buffered base board.

This is not it, but it starts with a very dubious push-on push-off
MOSFET circuit.  I doubt it really works, even if it simulates
beautifully.  But I don't simulate any debounce issues etc, although I
don't see why it wouldn't deal with that too.

All the real push-on push-off circuits I've seen are more complex than
this, which is the main reason why I doubt that my simple circuit really
works.  It's a bit *too* simple.  Everybody uses some flip-flop and/or
schmitt trigger or other fancier things.

But hey, maybe my google-fu is weak and I just didn't find the right
thing and there are even simpler ways to do this.  Plus I admittedly
came at this from an odd direction of "what can I do with discrete
MOSFETs".  Sane people don't do that.

Anyway, the basic of the push-on push-off circuit is - as always - a
capacitor that alternates between being discharged and charged up.  Then
two transistors that reinforce each other's state.

In this case, the capacitor is connected to the gate of the PMOSFET
through the momentary switch.  So if you press the switch and the
capacitor was discharged, the PMOSFET starts conducting, while if you
press the switch and the capacitor was charged, the PMOSFET turns off.

The rest of the circuit is just the complementary NMOSFET that then
follows the PMOSFET state and re-inforces whatever state it was in, and
the resistors to make it all work sanely.  The only important thing is
to make sure the resistors have sane values to not do bad things while
the switch is pressed.

It all simulates ok, and I don't see why it wouldn't work.

Anyway, this *only* does that silly push-on push-off logic.  It isn't
actually hooked up any way yet.  Not even the LED to show the state,
much less any JFETs to switch the actual signal around.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add a few dual MOSFET symbols

So I think I mostly understand JFETs, and I did BJT's earlier, so now
it's time for some MOSFET love.  Sure, I've used a P-channel MOSFET for
the high-side power thing, but that's still just trivial switching.  I
need to learn the whole small-signal AC thing and biasing etc.

And since I like the dual transistor form factors, and TSOT-23-6 is
about the right size for me, here's three different ones:

 - DMN3060LVT: dual N-channel MOSFET
 - DMP3164LVT: dual P-channel MOSFET
 - DMC3071LVT: dual complementary MOSFET

all three are fairly similar: 30V breakdown voltages, capable of a
couple of amps.  The complementary one is a bit beefier and has slightly
higher V_{TH} values, but we're still looking at roughly the same kind
of thing.

Let's see what I can do with these.  I didn't actually pick these based
on any sane and deep characteristics, they may be entirely the wrong
thing, but that's what we're going to find out.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Update compressor PCB layout too

This does the new trial matches JFET thing as a board layout too.  I'm
really not convinced this was worth it, and the routing and layout are a
bit of a mess, but it's all part of the whole learnign experience, and I
do want to see if the self-biasing thing actually works in real life or
it just happens to look ok in simulation with the particular simulation
values.

.. and the usual noise from KiCad inexplicably changing randon things
when looking at files.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Compressor: base the compressor level voltage on matched JFET

This is an attempt at basing the compression level voltage on the
matched JFET, making the level knob hopefully more reliably sane in the
face of different JFET characteristics.

I'm not entirely convinced I shouldn't just use a trim pot, but I do
think this is a more interesting approach.  It basically picks the base
voltage from the self-biasing voltage of the matched JFET, guaranteeing
that the level voltage pot starts close to V_{GSOFF}.  The level pot is
then basically controlling the DC bias on top of that.

This also tries to make the actual attentuation circuit clearer and
hopefully better.  Both the JFET drain and source are biased to the
compression level voltage, while the base is biased to the signal peak
detector (the somewhat mis-named "RECT" net).

The source then also gets the signal, and when V_{GS} gets close to zero
(ie RECT gets close to LEVEL) the JFET starts conducting and the AC
signal is attenuated through the JFET to the capacitor to ground at the
drain.

The base gets half the AC signal (on top of the DC peak bias) as before
to minimize distortion (ie the AC signal at the base is halfway between
the AC signal at source and the lack of AC signal at drain).

This all seems to still simulate well, and the behavior of the level pot
seems to mostly make sense.  How well it works with actual random JFET
characteristics and whether the matching model works, I don't know.

I still need to actually lay out the PCB, but I think the schematic is
getting closer.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Update compressor for the LS844 dual JFET

This is just a quick conversion, not using the matching, just using the
LS844 as two independent JFETs.

Because I_{DSS} is lower, the source resistor on the input buffer is
bigger, so that if I_{DSS} is just 1.5mA the voltage drop over the
resistor can go up to 3.5V.

Similarly, tweak the limit resistor values to give a bigger limit
voltage range for the bigger V_{GSOFF} range of the LS844, and make the
negative feedback resistor divider bigger to account for higher R_{DSON}
of the LS844.

Also remove the partial bypassing of the amplification emitter resistor,
since the high-frequency damping of the plain base is no more.  Although
maybe it wants a brighter sound?

This seems to simulate ok, although the compression is certainly not
identical to the version with the MMBF5103.  That may be real, or may be
just different spice model default values and swamped by JFET
variations.

Anyway, I'll eventually try the "use self-biasing using the matching
JFETs to do automatic levels" eventually, but first I wanted to do the
minimal conversion and verify that at least the LS844 model seems to be
ok before doing any bigger surgery.

NOTE! This doesn't update the PCB layout for the changes.  Just doing
the schematic and simulation checks.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Update the plain base to have a 1k RF resistor

That's what the text on the silkscreen said, but I had tested with a 10k
resistor (for a 72kHz low pass filter).  But I think it's safer to
really only filter out RF (3dB at 723kHz), so make it actually match the
text.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add LS844 dual matched JFET symbol

I'm not loving the JFET level tuning in the compressor pedal, so I have
the glimmers of a plan.  Using a dual matched JFET I think I can use
self-biasing on one of the JFETs to get it into the interesting region,
and then use the resulting source voltage as the level voltage.

Will that work? Who knows, but this adds the symbol and the simulation
data for it so that I can try it out.

It sounds a bit wasteful to use one JFET just for that, but I've liked
the other dual transistor parts, so maybe I'll use this one for other
things too where I just want two JFETs even if I don't care about the
matching.

The LS844 seems like a perfectly cromulent JFET to use in general, with
a reasonable V_{GSOFF} range (-1...-3.5V) and I_{DSS} (1.5...15mA).

Compared to the MMBF5103, it has lower I_{DSS} and a slightly larger
V_{GSOFF} range, but if the matching helps with the variation the latter
should be fine.

If I read the datasheets right, the on-resistance of the LS844 seems to
be rather higher in the 100-200 Ohm range.  That too seems ok, but may
need tweaking when converting a circuit.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Compressor: More kicad file noise

This just re-annotates the schematic and undoes the workaround for the
kicad bug with crossed wires that has now been fixed.

Link: https://gitlab.com/kicad/code/kicad/-/issues/21480
Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Octaver: file noise due to kicad version update

This also works around a bug in this pre-release of kicad: four wires in
the schematic that meet in the middle have their connections removed, so
you end up with two crossing wires rather than four connecting wires.

Quite annoying, but for now the workaround seems to be to just never
have a join of four wires coming together, but do two three-wire
connections.

I'm sure it will get fixed soon in Kicad, but I have been tracking
random daily source versions and rather than downgrade to a working
version, I'm working around this misfeature.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Plain base: noise from kicad version update

Nothing changed, just output from loading and saving the files with a
slightly newer kicad version.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Update some compressor component values based on testing

I think I was being a bit too timid wrt the compressor, making it a bit
boring.  It definitely works, but it looks more interesting with a much
more aggressive compression ratio, and a more aggressive signal
amplification to match.

The level trim pot was also slow to respond because the capacitor to
keep it stable was fairly large.

Also, partially bypass the emitter resistor in the amplification stage
to give higher frequencies a bit more oomph - the AC signal analysis
claims they otherwise attenuated over 10kHz.

Most of this was tested with the old boards (just changed components).
And other parts are "this looks better in simulation" (eg the emitter
resistor bypassing).

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>
Linux 6.17-rc4

Merge tag 'x86_urgent_for_v6.17_rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tip/tip

Pull x86 fixes from Borislav Petkov:

 - Convert the SSB mitigation to the attack vector controls which got
   forgotten at the time

 - Prevent the CPUID topology hierarchy detection on AMD from
   overwriting the correct initial APIC ID

 - Fix the case of a machine shipping without microcode in the BIOS, in
   the AMD microcode loader

 - Correct the Pentium 4 model range which has a constant TSC

* tag 'x86_urgent_for_v6.17_rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tip/tip:
  x86/bugs: Add attack vector controls for SSB
  x86/cpu/topology: Use initial APIC ID from XTOPOLOGY leaf on AMD/HYGON
  x86/microcode/AMD: Handle the case of no BIOS microcode
  x86/cpu/intel: Fix the constant_tsc model check for Pentium 4

Merge tag 'sched_urgent_for_v6.17_rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tip/tip

Pull scheduler fixes from Borislav Petkov:

 - Fix a stall on the CPU offline path due to mis-counting a deadline
   server task twice as part of the runqueue's running tasks count

 - Fix a realtime tasks starvation case where failure to enqueue a timer
   whose expiration time is already in the past would cause repeated
   attempts to re-enqueue a deadline server task which leads to starving
   the former, realtime one

 - Prevent a delayed deadline server task stop from breaking the
   per-runqueue bandwidth tracking

 - Have a function checking whether the deadline server task has
   stopped, return the correct value

* tag 'sched_urgent_for_v6.17_rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tip/tip:
  sched/deadline: Don't count nr_running for dl_server proxy tasks
  sched/deadline: Fix RT task potential starvation when expiry time passed
  sched/deadline: Always stop dl-server before changing parameters
  sched/deadline: Fix dl_server_stopped()

Merge tag 'irq_urgent_for_v6.17_rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tip/tip

Pull irq fixes from Borislav Petkov:

 - Remove unnecessary and noisy WARN_ONs in gic-v5's init path

 - Avoid a kmemleak false positive for the gic-v5's L2 IST table entries

 - Fix a retval check in mvebu-gicp's probe function

 - Fix a wrong conversion to guards in atmel-aic[5] irqchip

* tag 'irq_urgent_for_v6.17_rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/tip/tip:
  irqchip/gic-v5: Remove undue WARN_ON()s in the IRS affinity parsing
  irqchip/gic-v5: Fix kmemleak L2 IST table entries false positives
  irqchip/mvebu-gicp: Fix an IS_ERR() vs NULL check in probe()
  irqchip/atmel-aic[5]: Fix incorrect lock guard conversion

Merge tag 'hardening-v6.17-rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/kees/linux

Pull hardening fixes from Kees Cook:

 - ARM: stacktrace: include asm/sections.h in asm/stacktrace.h (Arnd
   Bergmann)

 - ubsan: Fix incorrect hand-side used in handle (Junhui Pei)

 - hardening: Require clang 20.1.0 for __counted_by (Nathan Chancellor)

* tag 'hardening-v6.17-rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/kees/linux:
  hardening: Require clang 20.1.0 for __counted_by
  ARM: stacktrace: include asm/sections.h in asm/stacktrace.h
  ubsan: Fix incorrect hand-side used in handle

Merge tag 'gpio-fixes-for-v6.17-rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/brgl/linux

Pull gpio fixes from Bartosz Golaszewski:

 - fix an off-by-one bug in interrupt handling in gpio-timberdale

 - update MAINTAINERS

* tag 'gpio-fixes-for-v6.17-rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/brgl/linux:
  MAINTAINERS: Change Altera-PIO driver maintainer
  gpio: timberdale: fix off-by-one in IRQ type boundary check

Merge tag 'arm64-fixes' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/arm64/linux

Pull arm64 fixes from Catalin Marinas:

 - CFI failure due to kpti_ng_pgd_alloc() signature mismatch

 - Underallocation bug in the SVE ptrace kselftest

* tag 'arm64-fixes' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/arm64/linux:
  kselftest/arm64: Don't open code SVE_PT_SIZE() in fp-ptrace
  arm64: mm: Fix CFI failure due to kpti_ng_pgd_alloc function signature

kselftest/arm64: Don't open code SVE_PT_SIZE() in fp-ptrace

In fp-trace when allocating a buffer to write SVE register data we open
code the addition of the header size to the VL depeendent register data
size, which lead to an underallocation bug when we cut'n'pasted the code
for FPSIMD format writes. Use the SVE_PT_SIZE() macro that the kernel
UAPI provides for this.

Fixes: b84d2b27954f ("kselftest/arm64: Test FPSIMD format data writes via NT_ARM_SVE in fp-ptrace")
Signed-off-by: Mark Brown <broonie@kernel.org>
Link: https://lore.kernel.org/r/20250812-arm64-fp-trace-macro-v1-1-317cfff986a5@kernel.org
Signed-off-by: Catalin Marinas <catalin.marinas@arm.com>

arm64: mm: Fix CFI failure due to kpti_ng_pgd_alloc function signature

Seen during KPTI initialization:

  CFI failure at create_kpti_ng_temp_pgd+0x124/0xce8 (target: kpti_ng_pgd_alloc+0x0/0x14; expected type: 0xd61b88b6)

The call site is alloc_init_pud() at arch/arm64/mm/mmu.c:

  pud_phys = pgtable_alloc(TABLE_PUD);

alloc_init_pud() has the prototype:

  static void alloc_init_pud(p4d_t *p4dp, unsigned long addr, unsigned long end,
                             phys_addr_t phys, pgprot_t prot,
                             phys_addr_t (*pgtable_alloc)(enum pgtable_type),
                             int flags)

where the pgtable_alloc() prototype is declared.

The target (kpti_ng_pgd_alloc) is used in arch/arm64/kernel/cpufeature.c:

  create_kpti_ng_temp_pgd(kpti_ng_temp_pgd, __pa(alloc), KPTI_NG_TEMP_VA,
                          PAGE_SIZE, PAGE_KERNEL, kpti_ng_pgd_alloc, 0);

which is an alias for __create_pgd_mapping_locked() with prototype:

  extern __alias(__create_pgd_mapping_locked)
  void create_kpti_ng_temp_pgd(pgd_t *pgdir, phys_addr_t phys,
                               unsigned long virt,
                               phys_addr_t size, pgprot_t prot,
                               phys_addr_t (*pgtable_alloc)(enum pgtable_type),
                               int flags);

__create_pgd_mapping_locked() passes the function pointer down:

  __create_pgd_mapping_locked() -> alloc_init_p4d() -> alloc_init_pud()

But the target function (kpti_ng_pgd_alloc) has the wrong signature:

  static phys_addr_t __init kpti_ng_pgd_alloc(int shift);

The "int" should be "enum pgtable_type".

To make "enum pgtable_type" available to cpufeature.c, move
enum pgtable_type definition from arch/arm64/mm/mmu.c to
arch/arm64/include/asm/mmu.h.

Adjust kpti_ng_pgd_alloc to use "enum pgtable_type" instead of "int".
The function behavior remains identical (parameter is unused).

Fixes: c64f46ee1377 ("arm64: mm: use enum to identify pgtable level instead of *_SHIFT")
Cc: <stable@vger.kernel.org> # 6.16.x
Signed-off-by: Kees Cook <kees@kernel.org>
Acked-by: Ard Biesheuvel <ardb@kernel.org>
Link: https://lore.kernel.org/r/20250829190721.it.373-kees@kernel.org
Reviewed-by: Ryan Roberts <ryan.roberts@arm.com>
Signed-off-by: Catalin Marinas <catalin.marinas@arm.com>

Merge tag 'for-linus' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/virt/kvm/kvm

Pull kvm fixes from Paolo Bonzini:
 "ARM:

   - Correctly handle 'invariant' system registers for protected VMs

   - Improved handling of VNCR data aborts, including external aborts

   - Fixes for handling of FEAT_RAS for NV guests, providing a sane
     fault context during SEA injection and preventing the use of
     RASv1p1 fault injection hardware

   - Ensure that page table destruction when a VM is destroyed gives an
     opportunity to reschedule

   - Large fix to KVM's infrastructure for managing guest context loaded
     on the CPU, addressing issues where the output of AT emulation
     doesn't get reflected to the guest

   - Fix AT S12 emulation to actually perform stage-2 translation when
     necessary

   - Avoid attempting vLPI irqbypass when GICv4 has been explicitly
     disabled for a VM

   - Minor KVM + selftest fixes

  RISC-V:

   - Fix pte settings within kvm_riscv_gstage_ioremap()

   - Fix comments in kvm_riscv_check_vcpu_requests()

   - Fix stack overrun when setting vlenb via ONE_REG

  x86:

   - Use array_index_nospec() to sanitize the target vCPU ID when
     handling PV IPIs and yields as the ID is guest-controlled.

   - Drop a superfluous cpumask_empty() check when reclaiming SEV
     memory, as the common case, by far, is that at least one CPU will
     have entered the VM, and wbnoinvd_on_cpus_mask() will naturally
     handle the rare case where the set of have_run_cpus is empty.

  Selftests (not KVM):

   - Rename the is_signed_type() macro in kselftest_harness.h to
     is_signed_var() to fix a collision with linux/overflow.h. The
     collision generates compiler warnings due to the two macros having
     different meaning"

* tag 'for-linus' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/virt/kvm/kvm: (29 commits)
  KVM: arm64: nv: Fix ATS12 handling of single-stage translation
  KVM: arm64: Remove __vcpu_{read,write}_sys_reg_{from,to}_cpu()
  KVM: arm64: Fix vcpu_{read,write}_sys_reg() accessors
  KVM: arm64: Simplify sysreg access on exception delivery
  KVM: arm64: Check for SYSREGS_ON_CPU before accessing the 32bit state
  RISC-V: KVM: fix stack overrun when loading vlenb
  RISC-V: KVM: Correct kvm_riscv_check_vcpu_requests() comment
  RISC-V: KVM: Fix pte settings within kvm_riscv_gstage_ioremap()
  KVM: arm64: selftests: Sync ID_AA64MMFR3_EL1 in set_id_regs
  KVM: arm64: Get rid of ARM64_FEATURE_MASK()
  KVM: arm64: Make ID_AA64PFR1_EL1.RAS_frac writable
  KVM: arm64: Make ID_AA64PFR0_EL1.RAS writable
  KVM: arm64: Ignore HCR_EL2.FIEN set by L1 guest's EL2
  KVM: arm64: Handle RASv1p1 registers
  arm64: Add capability denoting FEAT_RASv1p1
  KVM: arm64: Reschedule as needed when destroying the stage-2 page-tables
  KVM: arm64: Split kvm_pgtable_stage2_destroy()
  selftests: harness: Rename is_signed_type() to avoid collision with overflow.h
  KVM: SEV: don't check have_run_cpus in sev_writeback_caches()
  KVM: arm64: Correctly populate FAR_EL2 on nested SEA injection
  ...

hardening: Require clang 20.1.0 for __counted_by

After an innocuous change in -next that modified a structure that
contains __counted_by, clang-19 start crashing when building certain
files in drivers/gpu/drm/xe. When assertions are enabled, the more
descriptive failure is:

  clang: clang/lib/AST/RecordLayoutBuilder.cpp:3335: const ASTRecordLayout &clang::ASTContext::getASTRecordLayout(const RecordDecl *) const: Assertion `D && "Cannot get layout of forward declarations!"' failed.

According to a reverse bisect, a tangential change to the LLVM IR
generation phase of clang during the LLVM 20 development cycle [1]
resolves this problem. Bump the version of clang that enables
CONFIG_CC_HAS_COUNTED_BY to 20.1.0 to ensure that this issue cannot be
hit.

Link: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/160fb1121cdf703c3ef5e61fb26c5659eb581489 [1]
Signed-off-by: Nathan Chancellor <nathan@kernel.org>
Reviewed-by: Justin Stitt <justinstitt@google.com>
Link: https://lore.kernel.org/r/20250807-fix-counted_by-clang-19-v1-1-902c86c1d515@kernel.org
Signed-off-by: Kees Cook <kees@kernel.org>

Merge tag 'kvmarm-fixes-6.17-1' of https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/kvmarm/kvmarm into HEAD

KVM/arm64 changes for 6.17, take #2

 - Correctly handle 'invariant' system registers for protected VMs

 - Improved handling of VNCR data aborts, including external aborts

 - Fixes for handling of FEAT_RAS for NV guests, providing a sane
   fault context during SEA injection and preventing the use of
   RASv1p1 fault injection hardware

 - Ensure that page table destruction when a VM is destroyed gives an
   opportunity to reschedule

 - Large fix to KVM's infrastructure for managing guest context loaded
   on the CPU, addressing issues where the output of AT emulation
   doesn't get reflected to the guest

 - Fix AT S12 emulation to actually perform stage-2 translation when
   necessary

 - Avoid attempting vLPI irqbypass when GICv4 has been explicitly
   disabled for a VM

 - Minor KVM + selftest fixes

Merge tag 'kvm-riscv-fixes-6.17-1' of https://github.com/kvm-riscv/linux into HEAD

KVM/riscv fixes for 6.17, take #1

- Fix pte settings within kvm_riscv_gstage_ioremap()
- Fix comments in kvm_riscv_check_vcpu_requests()
- Fix stack overrun when setting vlenb via ONE_REG

Merge tag 'efi-fixes-for-v6.17-1' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/efi/efi

Pull EFI fixes from Ard Biesheuvel:

 - Assorted fixes for the OP-TEE based pseudo-EFI variable store

 - Fix for an OOB access when looking up the same non-existing efivarfs
   entry multiple times in parallel

* tag 'efi-fixes-for-v6.17-1' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/efi/efi:

Merge tag 'v6.17-rc3-smb3-client-fixes' of git://git.samba.org/sfrench/cifs-2.6

Pull smb client fixes from Steve French:

 - Fix possible refcount leak in compound operations

 - Fix remap_file_range() return code mapping, found by generic/157

* tag 'v6.17-rc3-smb3-client-fixes' of git://git.samba.org/sfrench/cifs-2.6:

Merge tag 'xfs-fixes-6.17-rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/fs/xfs/xfs-linux

Pull xfs fixes from Carlos Maiolino:
 "The highlight I'd like to point here is related to the XFS_RT
  Kconfig, which has been updated to be enabled by default now if
  CONFIG_BLK_DEV_ZONED is enabled.

  This also contains a few fixes for zoned devices support in XFS,
  specially related to swapon requests in inodes belonging to the zoned
  FS.

  A null-ptr dereference fix in the xattr data, due to a mishandling of
  medium errors generated by block devices is also included"

Merge tag 'hid-for-linus-2025082901' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/hid/hid

Pull HID fixes from Jiri Kosina:

 - fixes for memory corruption in intel-thc-hid, hid-multitouch,
   hid-mcp2221 and hid-asus (Aaron Ma, Qasim Ijaz, Arnaud Lecomte)

 - power management/resume fix for intel-ish-hid (Zhang Lixu)

 - driver reinitialization fix for intel-thc-hid (Even Xu)

 - ensure that battery level status is reported as soon as possible,
   which is required at least for some Android use-cases (Jos Expsito)

 - quite a few new device ID additions and device-specific quirks

  HID: input: rename hidinput_set_battery_charge_status()
  HID: intel-thc-hid: Intel-quicki2c: Enhance driver re-install flow
  HID: hid-ntrig: fix unable to handle page fault in ntrig_report_version()
  HID: asus: fix UAF via HID_CLAIMED_INPUT validation
  hid: fix I2C read buffer overflow in raw_event() for mcp2221
  HID: wacom: Add a new Art Pen 2
  HID: multitouch: fix slab out-of-bounds access in mt_report_fixup()
  HID: Kconfig: Fix spelling mistake "enthropy" -> "entropy"
  HID: intel-ish-hid: Increase ISHTP resume ack timeout to 300ms

Pull regulator fix from Mark Brown:
 "One simple fix for the pm8008 driver for poor error handling,
  switching to use a helper which does the right thing in the
  affected case"

Merge tag 'ata-6.17-rc4' of git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/libata/linux

Pull ata fixes from Damien Le Moal:

 - Fix the type of return values to be signed in the ahci_xgen driver
   (Qianfeng)

 - Add the mask_port_ext module parameter to the ahci driver.

   This is to allow a user to ignore ports that are advertized as
   external (hotplug capable) in favor of lower link power management
   policies instead of the default max_performance for these ports.

   This is useful to allow e.g. laptops to go into low power states when
   hooked up to docking station with sata slots, connected with an
   external port for hotplug (me)

Merge tag 'drm-fixes-2025-08-29' of https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/drm/kernel

Pull drm fixes from Dave Airlie:
 "Weekly fixes, feels a bit big.

  The major piece is msm fixes, then the usual amdgpu/xe along with some
  mediatek and nouveau fixes and a tegra revert.

  gpuvm:
   - fix some typos

  xe:
   - Fix user-fence race issue
   - Couple xe_vm fixes
   - Don't trigger rebind on initial dma-buf validation
   - Fix a build issue related to basename() posix vs gnu discrepancy

  amdgpu:
   - pin buffers while vmapping
   - UserQ fixes
   - Revert CSA fix
   - SR-IOV fix

  nouveau:
   - fix linear modifier
   - remove some dead code

  msm:
   - Core/GPU:
      - fix comment doc warning in gpuvm
      - fix build with KMS disabled
      - fix pgtable setup/teardown race
      - global fault counter fix
      - various error path fixes
      - GPU devcoredump snapshot fixes
      - handle in-place VM_BIND remaps to solve turnip vm update race
      - skip re-emitting IBs for unusable VMs
      - Don't use %pK through printk
      - moved display snapshot init earlier, fixing a crash
   - DPU:
      - Fixed crash in virtual plane checking code
      - Fixed mode comparison in virtual plane checking code
   - DSI:
      - Adjusted width of resulution-related registers
      - Fixed locking issue on 14nm PLLs
   - UBWC (per Bjorn's ack)
      - Added UBWC configuration for several missing platforms (fixing
        regression)

  mediatek:
   - Add error handling for old state CRTC in atomic_disable
   - Fix DSI host and panel bridge pre-enable order
   - Fix device/node reference count leaks in mtk_drm_get_all_drm_priv
   - mtk_hdmi: Fix inverted parameters in some regmap_update_bits calls

  tegra:
   - revert dma-buf change"

  drm/amdgpu/gfx11: set MQD as appriopriate for queue types

  drm/xe/xe_sync: avoid race during ufence signaling
  Revert "drm/tegra: Use dma_buf from GEM object instance"
  soc: qcom: use no-UBWC config for MSM8956/76

  drm/msm/dpu: Add a null ptr check for dpu_encoder_needs_modeset
  dt-bindings: display/msm: qcom,mdp5: drop lut clock
  drm/gpuvm: fix various typos in .c and .h gpuvm file

cairo, svg: ignore empty blocks

Fixes crash bug found with the afl fuzzer.

Signed-off-by: Max Kellermann <max.kellermann@gmail.com>

cairo,svg: convert "while" to "for" (code simplification)

Signed-off-by: Max Kellermann <max.kellermann@gmail.com>

pes: check the color index, fail if out of range

Fixes crash when there are more than 256 blocks.

Signed-off-by: Max Kellermann <max.kellermann@gmail.com>

pes: new_block() fails if undefined color is referenced

Fixes crash when the file's color table is too short.

Signed-off-by: Max Kellermann <max.kellermann@gmail.com>

pes: add missing new_block() error check

Signed-off-by: Max Kellermann <max.kellermann@gmail.com>

Mark the "big y displacement" case as a jumpstitch too

Another case pointed out by Trever and missed in his first patch.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Fix jumpstitch output

I noticed that your thumbnailer shows jump stitches yielding some ugly
thread lines in some cases.

I have attached a patch which solves this problem. Feel free to use it,
modify it, whatever.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Simplify and fix block allocation

This was just totally broken.  Since we used to re-alloc the pes blocks,
we cannot maintain a list of them: the pointers change.

So stop realloc'ing the blocks, and instead just realloc the stitch
list.  And simplify the list handling while at it.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add thumbnailer entry for gnome3

gnome3 changed the rules for how thumbnailer applications work.  For the
better, but without any real documentation.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

pesconvert: Fixed row init range in output_png().

This prevents a segfault for small embroidery patterns or large
output dimensions.

Even though output_png() is dead code, there is a slight chance,
that someone lacks libcairo-dev while being offline. ;-)

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add a 'density' argument for thread thickness

I like the default thin thread effect, but using a density of 2.5 or so
seems to be a bit more realistic on my test-case.  Which may be more
about the test-case than anything else, but whatever.

So with this, you can do something like

	pesconvert -d 2.5 -s 512 Jan_heartsdelight.pes s512.png

to generate a 512-pixel sized version of the Brother example file.

Making the "thread" thicker also meant that the line join matters a lot
more.  A miter join (the cairo default) is not how thread works and
makes it all look very jagged.  So make it use a round join instead.

The line cap could probably be a butt cap, but I set it to round too.  I
doubt anybody will see any difference, since thread ends aren't common.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Fix some trivial scaling problems

I used to scale everything to be square.  That was fine for testing, but
not so great for actual use.  This makes it all look better when the
input isn't square.  It also scales the width of the line properly.

And in honor of this actually being useful (it's installed on Tove's
machine now), let's sign off on it all.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Copy pesconvert to the system thumbnailer

Yeah, yeah, people who know how to do rpm's and autoconf think this is
ugly.  Whatever.
Teach pesconvert a few command line options

Add thumbnailer gnome gconftool-2 setting

.. not that the program actually conforms to the syntax I used, but
whatever. Maybe I'll get to it next.

Add silly rule to teach the system about PES files

XML? F*ck me with a ten-foot pole.  But if I want the thumbnailer, I
apparently need this.

Split out main() into its own file

This leaves the actual pes-reading code in pes.c, and puts the
conversion logic in main.c.

I should add some argument parsing code so that it can specify
exactly what/how to convert things.

Add a 'cairo' backend for output

This is way better and simpler than the png one, since cairo can also
write png's, but makes the line drawing and thin lines all very easy.

This is still totally hardcoded, but it's starting to be useful! It
outputs the result as "out.png"

Add stupid PNG support

It's stupid because:
 - it's fixed to output 128x128 png images (think preview icons)
 - it doesn't actually draw lines, it just does them as dots at the endpoints
but it does kind of work.

Initial PES conversion

Right now it just knows how to convert to SVG. Which isn't
all that interesting, but the parsing logic comes from

	https://bugs.launchpad.net/inkscape/+bug/247463

which has a php script to do this, and it's all based on that.

repository.name: test-tlb
repository.description: Stupid memory latency and TLB tester

commit.message:
README: minor typos fix

Verified with GNU Aspell spell checker.

Signed-off-by: Christopher Diaz Riveros <chrisadr@gentoo.org>
Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Improve on the timing logic a bit more

Time the warmup run to make a better estimate of how long to run the
real runs.  We want to balance getting timely results with still
actually having the time to actually traverse the full list a few times.

This basically aims for the real run to traverse the list at least five
times, but to also run for at least a fifth of a second.  Because five
is obviously a holy random number, and is also how many times we run the
test to try to de-noise the final number.

This also changes "make run" to actuall test the 256M case like the
README says (rather than stop at 128M).

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Improve on map re-allocation strategy

Don't bother reallocating hugepage mappings, the cache associativity
issues are hopefully not all that noticeable with big pages to begin
with, and with fewer big pages to go around it's likely less effective
to try to change the mapping anyway.

For the regular page case, force any remapping to over-map the old
mapping, which will free the old pages.  That might cause the new
mapping to have similar allocation patterns as the old one, but not
using excessive amounts of memory still makes this the better option.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Try to increase result stability by running multiple rounds

This runs things five times, randomizing the list in between each run,
and then picks the minimum cycle time of the five.  That makes the
results more stable.

There's a few downsides to this:

 (a) to avoid taking five times as long, each run only runs for half a
     second. Which might not actually be enough to go around for big
     memory areas.

 (b) is minimum cycle time actually good? It's _usually_ the right thing
     to do for latency benchmarks, but it might also end up showing the
     "good case", ie when the mapping happened to cause the fewest
     associativity misses etc.

 (c) the code is currently intentionally stupid and doesn't even free
     the old mappings, which is good to make sure that we don't get the
     same virtual memory pattern, but might cause problems when you want
     to test under low-memory conditions (just to pick one example).

I'll have to think about this some more, but let's try it.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Add README and LICENSE.txt file

... and a .gitignore file.

All prepping for putting it on github or something

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Allow odd stride values

They are actually quite useful for testing unaligned behavior: does it
slow down every access, or does it slow down only some accesses?

For example, on my i7-6700K, I get

	[torvalds@i7 test-tlb]$ ./test-tlb 16k 12
	  1.29ns (~5.0 cycles)

	[torvalds@i7 test-tlb]$ ./test-tlb 16k 11
	  1.36ns (~5.3 cycles)

which means that the unaligned load case is actually very low in pointer
chasing situations.  With a stride of 11, 75% of all the memory accesses
will be unaligned, but it only costs an additional 0.3 cycles on average.

The reason is that unaligned loads are basically free, except when they
cross some other boundary (*).  To test what the cost of that is, I'd
need to add a "offset" parameter and allow people to force every access
to be a bank crosser.

Some day.

(*) There may be other costs, like just resource use costs.  But the
kinds of boundaries that tend to matter are L1 D$ boundaries (that need
to access two lines), but also obviously page-crossers (that need two
TLB entries), and also sub-banks in the L1 (depending on width of the L1
interface).

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Work even in the presense of transparent hugepage  "always".

Christian Borntraeger tested on an s390, and had transparent hugepages
set to "always", which meant that the small-page case never triggered at
all.

So when not testing the hugepage case, explicitly do a

	madvise(MADV_NOHUGEPAGE)

on the memory allocation.

Reported-by: Christian Borntraeger <christian@borntraeger.net>
Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Use gettimeofday for start/end

In case your "alarm(1)" isn't entirely precise.
Improve the tester some more, remove the old TLB-only code

Try to create test of truly random list walker

.. with hugetlb and without.

It may be broken.
Very hacky TLB timing tester

repository.name: uemacs
repository.description: Random version of microemacs with my private modificatons

commit.message:
Allow bigger filenames

Not that I know why. 80-character filename limits are kind of cute.

Joerg suggested _POSIX_PATH_MAX, which is almost certainly the right
value.  But that's bigger than HUGE:

   #define HUGE    1000           /* Huge number                  */

which obviously means we shouldn't go quite *that* extreme.

Remember, we come from the days when it was hard to do allocations
larger than 64kB.   We have limits, dammit.

"256 bytes is enough for anybody"

Reported-by: Joerg Scheurich <mufti11@web.de>
Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-coundation.org>

Use _GNU_SOURCE instead of _BSD_SOURCE and _SYSV_SOURCE

uemacs uses a lot of legacy stuff, which causes warnings with newer
toolchains.

This makes it build reasonably warning-free.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Do some valgrind cleanup

Joerg Scheurich reported that there's a buffer overflow in readin() for
long path component names. He's not wrong.

When fixing that, and then checking there's nothing else obviously wrong
with valgrind, I also noticed it complains about overlapping strcpy().

So add a hacky version of strscpy(), which (a) handles overlapping, and
(b) has the proper strscpy() semantics.

Just say no to strncpy and strlcpy, both of which are terminally broken
interfaces.

And stop stripping the binary.  The time when the size of the uemacs
binary was a big deal is long past, and it made valgrind harder.

Reported-by: Joerg Scheurich <mufti11@web.de>
Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Merge branch 'experimental'

I'm not entirely happy with the new paragraph heuristics, but I've been
using them for a while and have grown used to them and have grown to
rely on the behavior.  Since there probably aren't all that many other
people who use uemacs, let's just merge that behavior and see if anybody
else even notices.

The "NBSP to SP on keyboard input" is similarly convenient to me, and
might be offensive to others.  Let's see.

* experimental:
  Turn NBSP into regular SP on input
  Try updated rule for "is new paragraph"
  Make some minor code legibility changes

Turn NBSP into regular SP on input

Particularly pasting from a web browser, I get a lot of 'space' +
'non-breaking space' noise, and keeping the &nbsp as an actual unicode
character ends up being a major pain.

Note: this is only done on input.  If the file contains the unicode
character U+00A0, we'll keep it that way.  But you can't enter it from
the keyboard (or cut-and-paste, which ends up looking like keyboard
input).

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Try updated rule for "is new paragraph"

This makes non-alphabetic characters at the beginning be a mark of a
paragraph.  That's probably bogus, but let's try how it works.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Make some minor code legibility changes

I'm going to play around with the whole "paragraph ends here" logic, but
the way it used to be written made that hard.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Don't use 'char' for number of lines

Heh.  My new UHD monitor makes it easy to have more than 127 lines of
text.  I guess the 'char' could be an unsigned char, but quite frankly,
trying to save a couple of bytes per open editor window seems a bit
excessive these days.  So just make it 'int'.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Stop using 'short' for line and allocation sizes

Yes, yes, it probably made sense 30 years ago as a way to save a tiny
amount of memory, but especially when interspersed in structures that
have pointers (aligned to 64 bits these days), it's not even saving
memory today.  And it makes us fail in nasty ways when looking at files
with long lines.

So just make them 'int'.  And if you have a line that is longer than
2GB, you only have yourself to blame.  I no longer care.

In case anybody care, the "test-case" for this was a lovely UDDF file
with a binary divecomputer dump encoded as an XML element.  Resulting in
a lovely 41kB single line.  Not what poor micro-emacs was designed for,
I'm afraid.

I really should just learn another editor, rather than continue to
polish this turd.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Avoid memory access errors if llength() overflows

llength() is currently a 'short' which can overflow and result in signed
numbers if line lengths are larger than 32k.  We'll fix the overflow
separately, but before we do that, just use a signed int to hold the
value so that we don't overrun memory allocations when we converted that
negative number to a large positive unsigned integer.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Fix the unicode character limit (0 .. 0x10ffff)

For some reason I had limited things to 0xffff, it really should be 0x10ffff.

We don't actually support a full 32-bit unicode model anyway, since we
use the high bits for the control/meta/^X/special bits, but there was no
reason to limit things to 16 bits when we had 28 bits available.  And
the real limit for real Unicode characters is 0x10ffff.

Add a silly example character past the 16-bit range to the UTF8 demo
file:
  'SMILING FACE WITH HALO' (U+1F607)
from the 'emoticons' block.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

uemacs: Remove unused 'lflag' variables from file.c

GCC spotted the following unused variable:

    CC       file.o
  file.c: In function readin:
  file.c:225:6: warning: variable lflag set but not used [-Wunused-but-set-variable]
  file.c: In function ifile:
  file.c:553:6: warning: variable lflag set but not used [-Wunused-but-set-variable]

Signed-off-by: Pekka Enberg <penberg@kernel.org>
Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Fix 'getccol()' and 'getgoal()' functions for multibyte UTF-8 characters

These functions convert the byte offset into the column number
(getccol()) and vice versa (getgoal()).

Getting this right means that moving up and down the text gets us the
right columns, rather than moving randomly left and right when you move
up and down.  We also won't end up in the middle of a utf-8 character,
because we're not just moving into some random byte offset, we're moving
into a proper column.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Fix vtputc() and simplify show_line by using it again

This re-introduces vtputc() as the way to show characters, which
reinstates the control character handing, and simplifies show_line() in
the process.

vtputc now takes an "int" that is either a unicode character or a signed
char (so negative values in the range [-1, -128] are considered to be
the same as [128, 255]).  This allows us to use it regardless of what
the source of data is.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Start doing character removal properly

This makes actual basic editing work.  Including things like
justify-paragraph etc, so lines get justified by number of UTF8
characters rather than bytes.

There are probably tons of broken stuff left, but this actually seems to
get the basics working right.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Start actually inserting full utf8 sequences

This makes it possible to cut-and-paste the UTF8 testfile into a new
buffer, and the end result looks correct.

NOTE! We still do various things wrong while editing.  For example,
while the cursor movements were fixed, simple things like deleting a
character still work on single bytes, rather than utf8 characters.

So while this is getting much closer to actually editing UTF-8 data,
it's not there yet.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Make 'show_line()' do proper TAB handling

The TAB handling got broken by commit cee00b0efb86 ("Show UTF-8 input as
UTF-8 output") when it stopped doing things one byte at a time.

I'm sure the other special character cases are broken too.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

Expand keycode to 'int' from 'short'

This uses the four high bits for the meta and control key sequences.
This means that we will be limiting our Unicode space to 28 bits, but
that's more than we really need.

It *would* be nicer if we just used the sign bit to mark "we have meta
character information") but that would require bigger changes.  And we
really don't need to worry about 30-bit unicode.  Small steps, remember.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

character input: make sure we have enough bytes for a full utf8 character

.. but we do have that 0.1s delay, so if somebody feeds us non-utf8
sequences, we won't delay forever.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>

utf8: make sure to honor the array length properly

Right now the input side can give partial utf8 input, and that showed
that we didn't properly handle that case.

Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@linux-foundation.org>
